nodes.bodyText:
findIn go through the automaton state successors to find CapturingGroupTrees
If we stop before the FinalState it's dangerous, we will not call markBackReferences for all groups.
For example:
A valid regex "(.)\\1(.)\\2" that can match "aabb" raises a false-positive.
Because findIn visits successors before filling the groupNames, so the back reference \\1 is an impossiblePath and we stop the visit.
the parameter visited has the same name as the field, so it could be confused by the reader.

IMO, the check will find a lot of CapturingGroupTree and a few BackReferenceTree.
And the current algorithm browses the tree to find the groups and from each group browses the tree to mark valid references. From a performance perspective, it's not good to do all those lookups for nothing.
I would prefer to first use a RegexBaseVisitor to collect all the BackReferenceTree, and to continue only if the list is not empty. Then the collected list can be used at the end instead of ImpossibleBackReferenceFinder visitor.
the \ should not be &bsol;, only HTML dev would understand 😉
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@ +

When a back reference in a regex refers to a capturing group that hasn't been defined yet (or at all), it can never be matched. Named back +references throw a PatternSyntaxException in that case; numeric back references fail silently when they can't match, simply making the +match fail.

+

When the group is defined before the back reference but on a different control path (like in (.)|\\1 for example),

nodes.bodyText: How do I fix this? I wrote \ in Jira because using a backslash there messes up the formatting in Jira.
